item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Biden Warns Invasion Still Possible Despite Russian Pullback Claim
item.description: The president said the United States has not verified the Russia has begun to withdraw troops and its forces “remain very much in a threatening position.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian tanks in the Rostov region, near the border with Ukraine, in January.

item.title: On Ukraine, U.S. and Russia Wage Signaling War to Avert Actual War
item.description: Each side is trying to convince the other that the price of conflict is too high. It is a complex game played with deliberate ambiguity, raising the risk of lethal miscalculation.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: American soldiers deploying to Eastern Europe on Monday at Fort Bragg, N.C.

item.title: Canada Live Updates: Ottawa Police Chief Resigns After Trudeau Declares National Emergency to End Protests
item.description: The extraordinary move allows the police to seize trucks used in blockades. And the government will formally ban demonstrations in areas like border crossings, airports and Ottawa, the country’s capital.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times

item.title: Former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez Detained
item.description: The request said Juan Orlando Hernández, who left office last month, was wanted in connection to a “violent drug-trafficking conspiracy.”
item.dc:creator: Joan Suazo and Anatoly Kurmanaev

item.title: For the Games, Xi Ordered Up a Snow Sports Fever. Will it Last?
item.description: China said it succeeded on a vow by Xi Jinping, the country’s top leader, to nurture millions of winter sports enthusiasts. But will the interest last after the Winter Games end?
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:description: Speedskating lessons at a park in Beijing last month. China is seeing a boom in winter sports.

item.title: A World Away From Ukraine, Russia Is Courting Latin America
item.description: The Ukraine crisis has revived a struggle over Latin America between the U.S. and Russia, as Vladimir V. Putin seeks greater influence in the region.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: An aerial view above Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in October.

item.title: In Italy, a Call for a National Investigation Into Clerical Sexual Abuse
item.description: Italy has so far resisted calls for an independent investigation into how the Roman Catholic church has handled these cases.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Italy has so far resisted calls for an independent inquiry, even after Pope Francis in 2019 held a landmark meeting on clerical sexual abuse at the Vatican.

item.title: In France, a Racist Conspiracy Theory Edges Into the Mainstream
item.description: Valérie Pécresse, the center-right presidential candidate, used the phrase ‘great replacement’ in a speech punctuated with coded attacks on immigrants and Muslims.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Valérie Pécresse, the center-right presidential candidate, said in a speech Sunday in Paris that France was not doomed to the “great replacement” and called on supporters “to rise up.”

item.title: Israeli leader, Naftali Bennett, Meets Bahrain Counterpart, Signaling Regional Shift
item.description: But the trip by Naftali Bennett, the first visit to Bahrain by an Israeli prime minister, also highlighted how the new relationship remains far from a society-wide compact.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Khalifa, Salman bin Hamad bin Isa al- (1969- )
item.media:credit: Haim Zach/Israeli Government, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In a photograph made available by the Israeli government, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel, center, with Crown Prince Salman bin Hamad al-Khalifa of Bahrain, right, in Manama, Bahrain, on Tuesday.

item.title: Navalny Faces 15 More Years in Prison as New Trial Starts in Russia
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, faces charges of embezzlement and contempt of court that could extend his time in jail by 15 years.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, center, is shown on a monitor during a court appearance Tuesday at the penal colony where he is being held in the Vladimir region of Russia.

item.title: Indonesian Teacher Convicted of Raping Students for Years
item.description: In a case that outraged the nation, the founder of a school was convicted of raping 13 students, fathering nine children with them.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Herry Wirawan being escorted to his trial at a court in Bandung, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: 10 Dead and Many Missing After Spanish Fishing Vessel Sinks in Atlantic
item.description: A fishing boat carrying 24 people sank about 280 miles off the coast of Newfoundland, Canada, early Tuesday morning, Spanish officials said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The Villa de Pitanxo, a 164-foot long vessel, at the Port of Marín, in Galicia, Spain in 2019.

item.title: Canada Protests Baffle a Nation of Rule Followers
item.description: The protests seem to challenge the cherished image that Canadians are moderate, rule-following and just plain nice. But was that really a myth all along?
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in downtown Ottawa this past weekend. “This is a myth-busting moment,” one analyst said.

item.title: Ukrainians Find Common Purpose in Opposing Russia
item.description: A trip along the Dnieper River explores what it means to be Ukrainian at a moment of extreme peril, as the country debates Russia’s place in its past, and its future.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:description: The fighting form of the Cossacks has seen a revival in the last few years.

item.title: Putin's Motives Pose a Challenge for U.S. Intelligence Agencies
item.description: Knowing the intentions of any autocratic leader is difficult, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who began his career as a K.G.B. officer, poses a particular challenge.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s calculus is likely shifting as he weighs the risks of an invasion against what he believes he could gain through negotiations, according to a U.S. official.

item.title: Prince Andrew’s Deal With Virginia Giuffre Leaves Many Questions
item.description: One question is who will pay for the settlement with the woman who accused him of raping her as a teen. But wider questions about his finances and behavior also dog the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Andrew last year.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Claims Some Troop Pullbacks
item.description: Biden warns that an invasion remains “distinctly possible.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia during a joint press conference with Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Tuesday.

item.title: Vehicle Crashes, Surging
item.description: Traffic deaths are surging during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deepshikha Nag Chowdhury and Aditya Bhattacharya’s son Pronoy Bhattacharya died while crossing the street with his family.

item.title: Travel Trends for Spring 2022
item.description: With Omicron cases ebbing, the industry is looking for a significant rebound in spring and summer. Here’s what to expect, in the air, at the rental car counter and beyond.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Germany’s chancellor meets with Putin as the tone of the crisis shifts.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany leaving for Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Requests Extradition of Former Honduran President
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández, who stepped down as president last month, was recently accused in a drug-trafficking case in federal court in New York.
item.dc:creator: Joan Suazo and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández, the former president of Honduras. His party was ousted in elections last year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine signals concessions as Russia mentions diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany during a news conference in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Justin Trudeau Invokes Rare Emergency Act to Quell Protests
item.description: “We cannot and will not allow illegal and dangerous activities to continue,” Canada’s prime minister said in a speech to the nation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in Ottawa Monday announcing the emergency order.

item.title: Sweden Recommends 4th Covid Vaccine Shots for People 80 and Older
item.description: It also warned, as the country removes its pandemic restrictions, that the virus is spreading increasingly among people who are at elevated risk of severe illness.
item.dc:creator: Matt Surman
item.media:credit: Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Waiting in line at a coronavirus vaccination site at Stockholm City Terminal station in Sweden last month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Talks of Diplomacy
item.description: Ukraine hinted at giving up its NATO ‘dream.’
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: A Russian submarine passing through the Bosphorus in Istanbul en route to the Black Sea on Sunday. Russia has reinforced its Black Sea fleet over the past week.

item.title: Canadians Donated Half of Funds for Trucker Protest, Leaked Data Shows
item.description: A close look at donor data — from crowdfunding campaigns to Bitcoin fund-raisers — reveals a cross-border mix of motives in support of the Canada convoy.
item.dc:creator: Mike McIntire and Michael H. Keller
item.media:description: Protesters in Ottawa on Monday.

item.title: Tone of Ukraine Crisis Shifts as Russia Signals Openness to Talk More
item.description: Diplomacy is “far from exhausted,” Russia’s foreign minister said, while President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said the prospect of his country joining NATO might be just a “dream.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front-line position in Krasnohorivka on Monday.

item.title: Protesters Begin Leaving Alberta's Coutts Border Crossing
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Allison Hannaford
item.media:credit: Royal Canadian Mounted Police, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo provided by Royal Canadian Mounted Police showing items seized after detentions at the border blockade, in Coutts, Alberta, on Monday.

item.title: The U.S. Is Closing Its Kyiv Embassy and Moving to Western Ukraine
item.description: The American secretary of state said the temporary embassy would remain engaged with the Ukrainian government.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Richard Pérez-Peña and Julian Barnes
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Zimbabwe Abruptly Closes Prosecution of Reporter for New York Times
item.description: Prosecutors ended their case against Jeffrey Moyo without calling key witnesses on Monday, prompting a move to dismiss a case that even government lawyers have called “shaky.”
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Jeffrey Moyo, a freelance reporter for The New York Times, was held for three weeks in jail last year after the government accused him of using faked press credentials — which he adamantly denies.

item.title: Luxury Resort in Spain Must Be Demolished, Court Finds
item.description: The complex at Marina Isla de Valdecañas, which includes a four-star hotel, was in breach of environmental rules, the Spanish Supreme Court said.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder

item.title: German Leader Vows Support for Ukraine, on Eve of Putin Meeting
item.description: The German leader said he would encourage business to invest in Ukraine, but ruled out sending weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ukraine Presidency/ Via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, left, with Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, ahead of their meeting in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: An Undiscovered Coronavirus? The Mystery of the ‘Russian Flu’
item.description: Scientists are grasping for any example that could help anticipate the future of Covid, even a mysterious respiratory pandemic that spread in the late 19th century.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Ontario will no longer require people show proof of vaccination to enter any indoor spaces.
item.description: Doug Ford, the premier, said that the change was based on the diminishing number of coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, and was not a concession to the protesters.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rollback of vaccine mandates for truckers who cross into the United States and re-enter Canada has been one of the key demand of the protesters in Ottawa.

item.title: Nicaragua Seizes Universities, Inching Toward Dictatorship
item.description: Many see the move as President Daniel Ortega’s latest effort to clamp down on dissent, after persecuting political opponents and extending his time in office.
item.dc:creator: Yubelka Mendoza and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: The Polytechnic University of Nicaragua was among several institutions brought under state control.

item.title: Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, Tests Positive for Covid-19
item.description: The announcement is likely to fan further concerns about the health of Queen Elizabeth II, who was in contact with Charles, her eldest son, two days before he tested positive.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stuart C. Wilson
item.media:description: Britain’s Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, during a visit to an animal shelter this month.

item.title: Israel's Prime Minister, Naftali Bennett, to Make Historic Visit to Bahrain
item.description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett landed in Bahrain on Monday in the first visit by an Israeli premier to the gulf state, which is seen as a proxy for Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Khalifa, Salman bin Hamad bin Isa al- (1969- )
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel, with Foreign Minister Abdullatif al-Zayani of Bahrain, after arriving in Bahrain on Monday.

item.title: China's Censors Have a New Target: 'Friends'
item.description: The popular sitcom has become the latest target of China’s censorship campaign. The awkward cuts have not been missed by fans of the show in the country.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Terence Patrick/HBO Max, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The stars of “Friends” — from left, Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox, Matthew Perry, Lisa Kudrow, David Schwimmer and Matt LeBlanc — in a scene from “Friends: The Reunion.”

item.title: A Guide to Protecting the Vulnerable from Covid
item.description: We offer a guide to protecting the elderly, immunocompromised and unvaccinated from Covid.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: N95 masks were distributed to farm workers in Medford, Ore.

item.title: Glimpses of Northern India’s Vanishing Nomads
item.description: For centuries, Kharnak nomads have raised livestock in one of the most hauntingly beautiful — and inhospitable — places on earth. Can their traditions outlast a generational exodus?
item.dc:creator: Ronald Patrick

item.title: China's Succession Drama, Starring Xi Jinping
item.description: As a party congress approaches, it’s increasingly clear that Xi Jinping plans another five-year term. But if he has ideas about a successor, he has hidden them well.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Xi Jinping arriving for the closing meeting of the National People’s Congress in March 2019 in Beijing.

item.title: Germany Is Trying to Rely Less on Russian Energy
item.description: An increasingly belligerent Russia, an energy crunch and a new Green minister of economics all add up to a change of direction in Germany’s policy on natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: The Nord Stream 2 pipeline is to transport natural gas directly from Russia to this receiving station near Lubmin, in northeastern Germany.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A climax nears in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at the front line in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: A remote island nation confronts its first confirmed coronavirus case.
item.description: The case in the Cook Islands emerged a month after the country reopened its air borders to travelers from New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.media:description: Passengers arrived in Auckland, New Zealand, last month from the Cook Islands after the two countries reopened their air borders.

item.title: Canada Opens Blockaded Bridge, but in Ottawa, Truckers Won’t Budge
item.description: Amid progress at a border bridge, Ottawa remained frozen by an antigovernment protest. There were signs of a slight thaw, with truckers said to be weighing pulling out of part of the capital.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: Police officers cleared demonstrators on Sunday from the road leading to the Ambassador Bridge linking Detroit and Windsor, Ontario.

item.title: Ukraine’s President Tries to Avert Panic as Pressure Mounts
item.description: With Ukraine at the center of Europe’s most intense security crisis of the post-Cold War era, President Zelensky is driving home his message of optimism.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at the front line in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: That Organic Cotton T-Shirt May Not Be as Organic as You Think
item.description: The organic cotton movement in India appears to be booming, but much of this growth is fake, say those who source, process and grow the cotton.
item.dc:creator: Alden Wicker, Emily Schmall, Suhasini Raj and Elizabeth Paton
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvested organic cotton at a bioRe facility in Kasrawad, India. India is the single largest producer of the world’s organic cotton, responsible for half of the supply.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Fears of Invasion Mount
item.description: Airlines suspend flights over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Saturday at the front line in Zaitseve, in eastern Ukraine. American officials believe that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may not yet have made a final decision to invade Ukraine.

item.title: Nepal’s Chief Justice Is Suspended, Deepening Political Chaos
item.description: Accusations and a possible ouster could aggravate divisions that have paralyzed much of the Nepal government for months.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Demonstrations last summer in Kathmandu, Nepal, against the chief justice of the country’s Supreme Court, Cholendra Shumsher Rana, who faces impeachment proceedings.
